tweets.text:
We're excited to start sharing first glimpses through our new underwater viewing fish pass window into the #RiverSevern at Diglis, Worcester!

And keep an eye out for lots more #FishOfTheSevern clips to come! #DiglisFishPass #FishWindow https://t.co/dksPNubdeV

Via the NEW Diglis fish pass, twaite shad can now swim past #Worcester on their #SevernShadRun for the first time in nearly 180yrs! üéâüêüüéâ 
Please watch & share our video! #FollowTheShad #FishMigration @CanalRiverTrust @severnrivers @EnvAgencyMids @HeritageFundM_E @LIFEprogramme https://t.co/kzh7NFPljc

urls.title: Communicating the importance of natural flood management to a global audience - Natural Course
urls.description: US Army Engineer Research and Development Centre host virtual book launch for Engineering with Nature: An Atlas, Volume 2 Book features a Natural Course supported case study about natural flood management initiatives at Smithills and Low Leighton (New Mills) A case study showing the benefits of natural flood management interventions installed at the Smithills site [‚Ä¶]

England is at risk of facing #WaterShortages by 2050 due to #ClimateChange and population growth.

We're working with water companies to tackle this challenge and protect our water supplies.

Find out how: https://t.co/3OsurzkVGO https://t.co/Lu2mHFgV6F

Very sad to see sanitary products in the sea when going for a high tide swim at Walpole bay just now @SouthernWater @EnvAgencySE @bbcsoutheast @IsleThanetNews @ThanetCouncil What is going on? No alert on @sascampaigns so no alert been given. Urgently need signs up now!

I‚Äôve not had any previous contact with @EnvAgency or @EnvAgencySE but it seems - for whatever reason - to be highly inefficient or even obstructive. Will you help @BrookersDollis? How best do we connect?

urls.title: B-lines | Shropshire Wildlife Trust
urls.description: The B-Lines are a series of ‚Äòinsect pathways‚Äô running through our countryside and towns, along which we are restoring and creating a series of wildflower-rich habitat stepping stones. They link existing wildlife areas together, creating a network, like a railway, that will weave across the British landscape.

tweets.text:
There are approx 220 chalk streams IN THE ENTIRE WORLD and Bury St Edmunds has two of them, the Lark and the Linnet. Chalk streams are rare and important habitats.

Here's a photo of the Lark today. #ChalkStreamsInCrisis https://t.co/gb6aJsmjbJ

@EnvAgency @NewsNBC @PHE_uk this is truly not on Nikki was moved 30 miles while in labour because the our hospital was full of landfill gas. @BBCPanorama @BBCWorld @ClareDinnisEA @MattHancock @SentinelStaffs #StopTheStink thinking of you Nikki @StinkStopthe https://t.co/ya1Ql6og8k
